calendar.p: The Julian calendar, as used in England before 1752. The year starts on March 25.

A Hebrew calendar dating from the creation of the world, based on biblical genealogy. The start date varies according to the biblical texts used. Here, based on the dates given for the same events in other formats, this calendar starts in 3962 BC.
A calendar dating from the Roman discovery of Britain. Based on the dates given for the same events in other formats, this calendar starts in 50 BC.

zone.list:
ffor mariages of Ladies Jacobus: Rebuffi
saieth . Si fillia Ducis nubat militi
dicetur Ducissa: quia est dignitas
gGeneris.
Dignitas generis maior est veniens
a patre excellentior est, quae venit
a Marito
Si tamen dignitas mariti sit maior
poterit vti nobilitate viri.
Our Customes agree with the Romans
in some thinges: but with the ffrenche
in moste.
In Germany (by custome) the sonnes
of Dukes are doe all beare the
Names of dukes & all their dowghteres:
are called duchesses. In like sorte
of Earles children.
The Germans & ffrenche borne in
obedience to the Imperiall Lawes,
yet in orders of Nobility & chiualry
are not tyed to them but to their owne
Customes: much more we (not sub=
iected therto, & beinge out of that homag)
may likwise followe our owne customes
of chyvalry.
With vs dukes sonnes are not dukes th e only
eldest succedeth in dignity & his ffather
lyvinge beareth the name of an Earle
& is in degree above all symple Earles.
Their yonger sonnes are all Lordes & in
degree above all Barons.
Their dowghters: are all Ladies, in degree
above all Countesses holdinge theire
name & place after they marry (if
they take to husbande a knighte esquier
or gentilman: but if they marry a noble
man; they followe his degree and
lose theire owne. / .
Likwise theldest sonne of an Earle
only succedeth in his ffathers dignity
beinge in his ffathers lifetime a Lord
in degree above all Barons.
These are Lordes & Ladies by custome
of Chiualrye beyond the memory of
man, as strong in this kind of operation
& in theire proper Courte, as any generall
Custome at the Common Lawe.
These are Lordes by the Auncient
Lawe, albeit the common lawe taketh
knowledge of no other Lordes but
Lordes of Parliamente & scarcely of
all these. Therfore an Argumente
drawen out of forme in the Como nplace
ought not to be a conclusion to no=
bilitye. at the Common Lawe.
It is the maner of that Courte for con=
servation of forme to varye in woordes
from the symple trewthe: yea & in
this case to terme some Barons knightes
which in deede are none./
Of dukedomes Earldomes & Baro=
nies, none are spoyled but by the
highest Criminall offences.
When De la poole was created Earle
of Suffolk: by thesame patent his wife
was created by name (a forme not
vsuall) Countesse for terme of her
life, which name by second mariage
could not be taken awaye.
The widowe of Henry:5:
maried with Owen Tewther.
The Countesse of Somerset
married: with De la poole.
Cicely dowghter: of:Edward:4: maried:
with Kyme.
The Lady: Parre. widdow:
to Henry:8: maried: Sir
Thomas: Seymor } And all of them reteyned theire stiles & dignities.
Common conveighances ffynes, and
Recordes are plentifull witnesses
of the like. And this Custome is
as olde as Englande itselfe.
When they take from women their name
& dignities & from Barons their name
of Lorde: it is to be vnderstoude
quantum ad formam fforencem & non aliter
.flourish.
Writts in Henry: 3: tyme served only
to calle to the parliament Barons al=
ready created made of which some
had theire Creations beyond mans
memory havinge sate in theyre
Baronies & stiles of absolute inhe=
ritance in ffeesymple Ab Digni=
tatem coniunctam feodo: & feodum con=
iunctum Dignitati.
Nothinge is more vntrowe then that Barons
the primer, materiall, & finall c....st
dignity of a Baron was to have
seate in parliamente.
After solempne institution of parliamente
a rate was agreed vpon for sufficiency
sufficiency in posessions & the persons
qualified accordingly might be called
to parliament by the kinges writte, & holde
that dignity to them & to theire heyres
in like maner as the Ancient Barons
dyd.
That Auncient Baronies & not writtes
made Barons: appereth by Baronies
granted to Religious houses by which
imediately the Abbotes & Pryors were
Lordes, & had power to clayme seate
in parliament.
Dignities with the Baronies passed by
succession to persons ecclesiasticall
& descended by common course of in
heritance to Laye men./
Creation by writte employeth a
feesymple.
There hathe bene question in tymes
past whether the Style & Armes
of a Baron made by writte should
descende to the heire generall a
woman: or to a male collaterall
heire. And sentence geven for
the heire generall.
The tytle of Duke, marquesse, Earle
have bene only Titles of Office
in olde tyme, & not patrimoniall
but that of Baron allwaies feodall.
& therfore cannot without manifest
iniury be restrayned to a bare
tytle of Office in parliament to the
disinherison of any heire generall
without some Cryme or forfaiture.
There is a principall Rule in Lawe
scilicet: Interest Reipublicae: ut digni
tates familiares s conseruentur.
The Lawes of nature & nations
doe permitte children to be beutified
with theire parentes Nobility pur=
chased or atchiued by worthye
desertes ./. ffor this consideration
in Germany all Princes children
(of bothe sexes) beare the names
of dignities vsed by theire parentes.
Oure fathers consideringe that none are
borne wise & verteous & that doughteres
are no lesse naturall childen then
sonnes, in defect of sonnes receved
then to right of inheritance: partly
for that it was not denied to a woman
to be wise & verteous; partly for that
a man may choose to his weake dowghter:
a wise sonne in lawe to his owne
comfort for the conservation of his
patrimony, & service of the common
weale: whereas a sonne must be
receaved with all his imperfections
as it pleaseth nature to frame
hym./
Women are admitted to tenures by
Martiall service which nature denieth
to theire sexe: but thesame is salued
with a priueledge of deputation. And
like priueledge is geven them in service
of witte writte not denied them by the lawe
of God, nature, or nations.
Women are not barred the parliamente by
nature, but by Custome.
Women are incapeable of inheritance
in publique or meere Judiciall offices.
A woman lady of a manour hath in her
owne right Jurisdiction of a Court
Baron & thesame kept in her owne name
& mynistreth iustice by her deputye.
The Lawe pronounceth the husband &
wife one bodye to make but one body
then in the eye of the Lawe, the service
done by the husband for the wife in
parliament, is done by an hable person,
And in reason the Courte is better served
with the presence of her husbande then with a
proxi of a Baron absent.
All speaches of kinges are not maxims
of Lawe.
In the case of mr Wymbishe the kinge gave
sentence that no husband of a Ba=
ronesse in her owne right should vse
the style of her dignity vntill he had
by her a childe by which he should be=
come Tenant by curtesy of her Ba=
ronye. ffor then by thesame Lawe
of England which gave hym title to the
Baronye he hathe tytle to the dignity
as parcell of his wyves inheritance
And so Baron by permission and
imputation of Lawe & not otherwise
by speciall suite & favour of the
Prynce.
Before this order whoso maried a
Baronesse in her owne righte ime=
diatly vsed her style which was thoughe
thoughe done rather by Prynces
permission then by warrant of Lawe
Not only by women that are reasonable
creatures but by dome thinges titles
or dignities are conveighed. As
the Castle of Arondell, maketh
the posessor and Earle, & thesame
fallinge to a woman enhableth her
to transmitte the dignity to her
sonne; & therwithall place in Par=
liment.
It is thought that there is a booke case
tendinge to this effect: that if the kinges
Baron dye leavinge dyuerse doughteres
the dignity is supposed to beat the
kinges disposition. And that it groun=
ded vpon a maxime in the Cyvile
Lawe that sayeth Regnum Ducatus,
Comitatus Baronatus sunt res in=
diuiduae. & cannot abide .2. heades.
Therfore a barony dismembred by
sisterss shifte cannot abide two
heades hathe the dignity extinct
but when it descendeth to one sole
daughter & heire it is otherwise.
